adventures.title: Nairobi Nightfall: CEO Spoof
adventures.description: Minutes before payroll, a neon spear-phish tries to hijack the CFO's M-Pesa float.
adventures.scenario: It's 8:57 PM overlooking Nairobi's CBD. A subject line screams "URGENT: MPESA FLOAT TOP-UP" from ceo@cyberpulse.c0m. The cadence is off, the signature lacks the usual Swahili motto, and the sender insists the finance bot is down. One wrong move and hundreds of payouts stall.

start.text: The email wants you to approve emergency funds before bots auto-freeze disbursements.

choices.text: Inspect full headers, SPF, and DMARC before touching anything
Forward to finance and click the embedded "Authorize" link
Call the CEO on Signal using a stored contact

headers.text: SPF fails, the reply-to is a random Gmail, and the domain uses a zero instead of an o.

choices.text: Spin up an incident bridge, freeze payouts, and share indicators
Reply-all with a warning and hope someone in IT blocks it quickly

call_ceo.text: The CEO answers groggily and confirms she never sent the email. She wants a containment plan in five minutes.

choices.text: Alert SOC, send screenshots, and move payouts to manual approval
Assume the warning is enough and return to prepping payroll

incident_room.text: SOC blocks the lookalike domain, issues mobile alerts, and praises the fast escalation.
incident_room.lesson: Verifying signals and launching a coordinated response keeps fraudsters from draining payment floats.

panic_reply.text: Half the company sees your warning but finance never freezes payouts. Two approvals slip through before SOC intervenes.
panic_reply.lesson: Awareness helps, but without decisive containment attackers still win precious minutes.

rush_payment.text: The link harvests credentials, the attacker reroutes funds, and auditors flag you as the origin.
rush_payment.lesson: Urgency is the spear-phisher's favorite weapon. Independent verification beats any shiny CTA.

containment.text: You feed indicators to SOC, finance halts payouts, and marketing drafts a transparency update.
containment.lesson: Trusted-channel verification plus swift escalation is the fastest way to defuse high-stakes spoofs.

false_calm.text: Without formal escalation, the attacker tries other executives overnight. SOC only hears about it the next day.
false_calm.lesson: Knowing it's fake isn't enough—document and broadcast the threat so others aren't blindsided.

adventures.title: Kilimani Breach Beacon
adventures.description: A dusty reused password from campus days resurfaces on a darknet feed mid-demo prep.
adventures.scenario: Your password manager pings during a SOC hackathon: a 2018 gaming forum login matches the pattern you still use for dashboard shortcuts. The same combo just hit a Telegram leak channel frequented by Kenyan threat crews. A board demo starts in 30 minutes.

start.text: The breach alert shows the exact stem you still reuse. Attackers love credential stuffing.

choices.text: Launch a full password reset wave with unique passphrases
Only change the old forum password—you'll revisit the rest later
Ignore it, the account was ancient anyway

reset_wave.text: You blitz through priority accounts, but MFA still lags on a few shared dashboards.

choices.text: Enable MFA everywhere, notify SOC, and brief the board that you're 5 minutes late
Skip the notification to avoid spooking leadership

token_loop.text: The obvious password is fixed, but clones still live inside automation scripts.

choices.text: Pause prep, enable MFA, and open an incident ticket
Wait until after the board demo to avoid delays

credential_stuffing.text: Attackers reuse the combo to break into your inbox, pivot into billing portals, and leak invoices.
credential_stuffing.lesson: Every exposed password matters. Delays give credential-stuffing crews time to weaponize your identity.
credential_stuffing.relatedArticle: Password Security and Data Breach Response

full_response.text: MFA is everywhere, SOC confirms no suspicious logins, and the board loves the transparency.
full_response.lesson: Comprehensive resets plus proactive comms turn potential incidents into trust-building stories.

quiet_patch.text: You dodge awkward conversations, but hours later a botnet replays the leaked password against a staging cluster.
quiet_patch.lesson: Silent fixes reduce embarrassment but invite repeat attacks. Share intel before attackers do.

adventures.title: Parking-Lot Payload
adventures.description: A glittery USB labeled "Safari Winners" appears beside your matatu slot. Tempting?
adventures.scenario: After a late-night meetup in Westlands you spot a chrome USB with a handwritten note promising travel vouchers. Last time this happened it was a red-team drill. This time you're not sure.

start.text: The USB is warm, suggesting recent use. A crowd is forming near the parking pay station.

choices.text: Pocket it and plug into your personal laptop to peek
Seal it in an evidence bag and walk to the SOC lab
Leave it untouched, snap a photo, and tell building security

lab_drop.text: SOC thanks you but asks whether you captured metadata or location details.

choices.text: Share timestamps, photos, and let them sandbox it
Drop it anonymously and hurry home

curiosity_trap.text: Auto-run launches, ransomware encrypts your photos, and the worm laterals via saved VPN creds.
curiosity_trap.lesson: Unknown media is attacker gold. Curiosity turns you into patient zero.

note_drop.text: Security collects the drive, but without context SOC can't map the risk radius.
note_drop.lesson: Not touching the device helps, but details boost threat hunting speed.

analysis_room.text: The drive is a red-team probe. Your evidence trail lets SOC brief leadership within minutes.
analysis_room.lesson: Chain-of-custody and context transform a suspicious object into actionable intelligence.

missing_context.text: SOC analyzes the drive but spends hours retracing your steps to assess exposure.
missing_context.lesson: Even good instincts need documentation. Details accelerate containment.

adventures.title: Ngong Road WiFi Gauntlet
adventures.description: Only options: sketchy café Wi-Fi or a throttled hotspot while a VIP client waits.
adventures.scenario: You're camped at a Nairobi coffee shop when legal pings: upload a sensitive land-registry packet within 10 minutes or the deal collapses. "CafeFree_5G" is blazing fast but infamous for rogue APs. Your phone hotspot is safer but crawling on one bar.

start.text: The client is watching the shared drive. Every minute counts.

choices.text: Use the free Wi-Fi and trust HTTPS
Switch to hotspot, throttle expectations, and prep VPN
Delay the upload until you reach a secure office

cafe_wifi.text: A man-in-the-middle strips HTTPS, steals session cookies, and the client portal locks your account.
cafe_wifi.lesson: Throughput is meaningless if the channel is hostile.
cafe_wifi.relatedArticle: Public WiFi Security and Secure Remote Work

hotspot_plan.text: Your hotspot holds but the VPN keeps dropping frames.

choices.text: Retry with split tunneling and prioritize upload traffic
Disable the VPN to gain speed

delay_trip.text: Legal warns the deadline is strict but prefers safe handling over breach headlines.

choices.text: Negotiate a 15-minute extension while you move to a trusted network
Drive back home without updating anyone

vpn_tunnel.text: The upload finishes with seconds to spare. Logs show encrypted traffic only.
vpn_tunnel.lesson: Controlled channels plus honest comms beat risky shortcuts.

forget_vpn.text: The upload succeeds, but compliance flags the unsecured transfer and demands a postmortem.
forget_vpn.lesson: Speed without safeguards invites audits and sleepless nights.

delay_more.text: You arrive at the office to find the client moved on. At least the data stayed safe.
delay_more.lesson: If you must delay, communicate and offer safe alternatives.

adventures.title: Shadow Access at the Data Bunker
adventures.description: A friendly engineer wants VIP access to the customer vault before sunrise—no ticket, no trail.
adventures.scenario: Your Signal buzzes at 5 AM: "Boss signed off, just slot me into the customer DB group so I can demo to investors." Change-control is frozen during migration, and granting access manually leaves zero audit trail.

start.text: The requester insists everyone does it this way during crunch time.

choices.text: Grant access immediately to keep the peace
Ping the manager and confirm there's written approval
Guide them through the emergency ticket flow yourself

verify_ticket.text: The manager approves the need but wants logging and time limits.

choices.text: Launch an emergency change bridge with SOC on the line
Document the chat and plan to update logs later

help_file_ticket.text: You co-write the ticket, but the engineer begs for immediate access while waiting.

choices.text: Escalate to IT to grant time-boxed access with monitoring
Share a temporary admin password so they can start sooner

instant_leak.text: The account was already compromised. Customer data is siphoned before sunrise.
instant_leak.lesson: Shortcuts are perfect cover for social engineering.

launch_bridge.text: IT grants least-privilege access, SOC monitors queries, and logs prove compliance.
launch_bridge.lesson: Even at 5 AM, process protects both the org and the relationship.
launch_bridge.relatedArticle: Access Control and Audit Trail Requirements

doc_only.text: You keep screenshots, but regulators later ask why SOC wasn't looped in.
doc_only.lesson: Documentation matters, but so does real-time oversight.

timeboxed_access.text: The demo succeeds, logs show every query, and leadership applauds the guard rails.
timeboxed_access.lesson: Helping teammates is great when you keep the controls locked.

slow_queue.text: The temp password leaks in a screenshot and harvesters hit the account within hours.
slow_queue.lesson: Even temporary creds expand the blast radius.

adventures.title: Boardroom Cliffhanger
adventures.description: An unlocked laptop beams payroll secrets onto a giant screen after midnight.
adventures.scenario: You're packing up from a midnight blue-team drill when a conference room door creaks. Inside: a laptop still logged in, projecting payroll CSVs. Cleaners are roaming the floor.

start.text: Highly sensitive salary data is visible from the hallway.

choices.text: Skim the spreadsheet to understand impact
Lock the workstation and document everything
Shut the door and plan to mention it tomorrow

snoop.text: Security cameras show you scrolling through staff salaries. HR opens an investigation.
snoop.lesson: Reading data you shouldn't see is still a breach.

lock_report.text: You lock the device, snap photos, and note the room number.

choices.text: Call the SOC hotline and hand over evidence
Leave a sticky note for the owner and head home

postpone.text: Hours pass before anyone notices. Cleaners could have photographed everything.
postpone.lesson: Delay equals exposure. Time matters even after midnight.

soc_call.text: SOC locks the account remotely, reviews logs, and sends a coaching note to the owner.
soc_call.lesson: Secure, document, escalate. In that order.

note_only.text: The owner appreciates the reminder, but there's no record for compliance.
note_only.lesson: Friendly notes can't replace formal reporting.

adventures.title: Wellness Week Wiretap
adventures.description: A fake HR wellness drive wants your bank PIN, TIN, and favorite smoothie recipe.
adventures.scenario: Monday morning, an email blasts the company: "Mandatory Wellness Week check-in—complete now for free gym credits." The link jumps to an external site asking for passwords and mobile money details. HR normally uses the intranet.

start.text: The countdown timer ticks down from 10 minutes.

choices.text: Fill the form quickly—free perks are rare
Call HR on their published extension
Drop a question in the general Slack channel first

full_compromise.text: Attackers capture your login, bank details, and pivot into payroll systems.
full_compromise.lesson: Legit HR never asks for passwords. Scarcity is bait.
full_compromise.relatedArticle: Advanced Phishing Techniques and Red Flags

call_hr.text: HR confirms it's fake and begs you to send the headers.

choices.text: Forward headers, screenshots, and phone details to SOC
Just tell your team lead; they'll handle it later

ask_chat.text: Colleagues are confused. Some already filled it out.

choices.text: Immediately escalate with HR and SOC
Wait for HR to respond in the channel

intel_dump.text: Security blocks the domain, mobile alerts go out, and your evidence appears in the next awareness deck.
intel_dump.lesson: Fast verification plus intel sharing shuts down phishing waves.
intel_dump.relatedArticle: Advanced Phishing Techniques and Red Flags

slow_alert.text: HR eventually responds, but dozens already surrendered data.
slow_alert.lesson: Crowdsourcing suspicion is fine, but escalation wins the race.

adventures.title: Cloud Kiondo Wide Open
adventures.description: A production bucket stuffed with ID scans is exposed to the entire internet.
adventures.scenario: While checking overnight metrics, you notice storage bucket "kiondo-prod" set to public read. It hosts national ID scans for onboarding. Policy says critical misconfigs must be contained within four hours, but your manager is offline in Eldoret.

start.text: The bucket's access logs show spikes from unfamiliar IPs.

choices.text: Flip it to private immediately and hope that's enough
Email your manager and wait
Apply emergency network rules and open an incident bridge

solo_patch.text: Access stops, but there's no record of what happened.

choices.text: Document everything and notify SOC anyway
Move on—no need to wake anyone

wait_manager.text: By the time you get a reply, a threat intel feed lists the bucket in a breach roundup.
wait_manager.lesson: Critical exposures need emergency channels, not inbox roulette.

isolate_bucket.text: You block public access via firewall rules and ping SOC with all the details.

choices.text: Launch a bridge, invite legal and data protection officers
Handle it with just you and SOC to keep it lightweight

bridge_mode.text: Legal confirms no exfiltration, regulators are notified, and runbooks get updated.
bridge_mode.lesson: Full visibility and documentation beat heroics every time.

solo_contain.text: You and SOC fix the issue, but compliance asks why privacy and legal weren't involved.
solo_contain.lesson: Containment without the right stakeholders invites governance headaches.

walkaway.text: Weeks later, auditors can't tell whether data leaked. You're on the hook for the gap.
walkaway.lesson: If it isn't documented, it didn't happen—and that's a problem.
